nodes.text: The empirical and methodological contributions of David Card, Joshua Angrist, and Guido Imbens transformed modern applied microeconomics by promoting a design-based approach that clarifies causal inference from natural experiments and instrumental variables

A research design emphasis—identifying sources of plausibly as-good-as-random variation and constructing appropriate comparison groups—improves internal credibility of causal claims in settings where randomized experiments are infeasible

David Card's empirical natural-experiment studies provided surprising causal evidence on labour topics (immigration, minimum wage, schooling) that challenged conventional wisdom and spurred follow-up research

Angrist and Imbens formalized IV causal interpretation using the potential outcomes framework and derived the Local Average Treatment Effect (LATE) result, clarifying what IV estimates identify under minimal assumptions

Design-based methods (RCTs, natural experiments, regression discontinuity, difference-in-differences, IV) are complementary: clear design increases internal validity while questions of external validity and heterogeneity require additional analysis or structural modeling
Method: Use of natural experiments and researcher-collected data to construct control groups and test identifying assumptions (e.g., border comparisons, custom surveys, linked administrative data)
Method: Emphasize explicit identifying assumptions (parallel trends, instrument exogeneity/exclusion/monotonicity) and subject them to falsification and balance checks
Evidence: Rise in use of causal language and design-based empirical strategies in economics since late 1980s, including increase in RCTs, diﬀerence-in-differences, and natural-experiment papers

Evidence (Mariel boatlift): Card (1990) compared Miami to selected similar cities after a large Cuban immigration shock and found little effect on native wages or employment, suggesting limited local labor-market impacts from that shock
Evidence (minimum wage): Card and Krueger (1994) used pre/post surveys across the New Jersey/Pennsylvania border and found no decline in fast-food employment after a 20% NJ minimum-wage increase

Evidence (schooling): Angrist and Krueger (1991) used quarter-of-birth instruments to show modest first-stage increases in schooling and IV estimates implying roughly 10 percent earnings return per additional year of schooling for compliers

Method/Result (LATE): Under random assignment of the instrument, exclusion, monotonicity, and relevance, the IV estimand identifies the Local Average Treatment Effect — the average treatment effect for compliers induced by the instrument

Claim: The LATE result separates internal validity (causal identification for compliers) from external validity (generalizability), making explicit that IV estimates reflect the subpopulation affected by the instrument

Result: Angrist (1990) used draft lottery assignment as an instrument and IV methods to estimate that Vietnam-era military service reduced later earnings for compliers (a substantial negative earnings effect in the studied cohorts)

Limitation: Design-based estimates often rely on narrow, context-specific sources of variation (small complier groups or unique shocks) so translating findings across settings requires modeling or additional evidence on heterogeneity

Conclusion: Together, Card's empirical use of natural experiments and Angrist and Imbens' formalization of IV/Potential Outcomes strengthened the scientific foundation of empirical economics by improving transparency about identifying assumptions and enabling credible causal inference when experiments are infeasible
